header.title: tags

erlref.modulesummary: Generate Emacs TAGS file from Erlang source files

description.p: A TAGS file is used by Emacs to find function and variable definitions in any source file in large projects. This module can generate a TAGS file from Erlang source files. It recognises functions, records, and macro definitions.

func.name: file(File [, Options])
func.fsummary: Create a TAGSfile for the file File.

desc.p: Create a TAGS file for the file File.

func.name: files(FileList [, Options])
func.fsummary: Create a TAGS file for the files in the listFileList.

desc.p: Create a TAGS file for the files in the list FileList.

func.name: dir(Dir [, Options])
func.fsummary: Create a TAGS file for all files in directoryDir.

desc.p: Create a TAGS file for all files in directory Dir.

func.name: dirs(DirList [, Options])
func.fsummary: Create a TAGS file for all files in any directory inDirList.

desc.p: Create a TAGS file for all files in any directory in DirList.

func.name: subdir(Dir [, Options])
func.fsummary: Descend recursively down the directory Dirand create a TAGSfile based on all files found.

desc.p: Descend recursively down the directory Dir and create a TAGS file based on all files found.

func.name: subdirs(DirList [, Options])
func.fsummary: Descend recursively down all the directories inDirListand create a TAGSfile based on all files found.

desc.p: Descend recursively down all the directories in DirList and create a TAGS file based on all files found.

func.name: root([Options])
func.fsummary: Create a TAGSfile covering all files in the Erlang distribution.

desc.p: Create a TAGS file covering all files in the Erlang distribution.

section.title: OPTIONS
section.p: The functions above have an optional argument, Options. It is a list which can contain the following elements:

list.item: {outfile, NameOfTAGSFile} Create a TAGS file named NameOfTAGSFile.
{outdir, NameOfDirectory} Create a file named TAGS in the directory NameOfDirectory.

section.p: The default behaviour is to create a file named TAGS in the current directory.

item.p: This command will create a file named root.TAGS in the current directory. The file will contain references to all Erlang source files in the Erlang distribution.
Here we create file named TAGS placed it in the directory ../projectdir. The file contains information about the functions, records, and macro definitions of the three files.

list.item: Richard M. Stallman. GNU Emacs Manual, chapter "Editing Programs", section "Tag Tables". Free Software Foundation, 1995.
Anders Lindgren. The Erlang editing mode for Emacs. Ericsson, 1998.
